Service Merchandise tightens belt; staff and expense reducti

NASHVILLE, TENN. -- Service Merchandise is once again in a precarious position. In the aftermath of weak December sales and an uncertain short-term retail outlook, the jewelry and hard lines retailer has decided to reduce expenses through the elimination of 1,750 jobs, as well as the consolidation of the chain's field structure, headquarters space and jewelry repair business.

Even though ceo Sam Cusano told DSN Retailing Today that the retailer isn't on the brink of closure, plans to emerge from bankruptcy this year may be postponed due to soft sales trends. With both Montgomery Ward and Bradlees announcing intentions to go out of business recently, the question lingered whether a similar fate might befall Service Merchandise.
"Service Merchandise still has a significant amount of liquidity and cash availability, and so we're not necessarily in the same position," Cusano said. "Our [holiday] performance wasn't the best, but it wasn't terrible."
Although the company would not reveal specific sales data prior to the release of its earnings report next month, Cusano said December sales were weak with negative comps. Even with cash availability in excess of $200 million, Service Merchandise is tightening the belt once again in an expense and staff reduction program that is intended to save $35 million. An earlier restructuring program announced last March trimmed $18 million.
"With our sales weaker than we had anticipated, it certainly encouraged us to look even harder at the expense structure, and we did so," Cusano said.
The most drastic of the measures is clearly the elimination of 1,750 jobs, a move that undoubtedly will be met with mixed reactions from Wall Street. While the cutbacks are a sure sign that the retailer is dedicated to its turnaround efforts, it also sends a message of despondency and quasi-desperation.

All the same, Cusano said the staff reductions fall in line with the reduced store size and scaled-down product selections implemented last year in the launch of a new format. The latest layoffs are on top of more than 4,800 jobs the company eliminated last year.
Staff reductions affected all levels of the organization, including senior management. At company headquarters, 120 jobs were eliminated, including that of president and coo Charles Septer. Cusano said he would assume the role as president, while Septer's other duties will be spread among senior executives.
Senior vp of jewelry Rose Septer has also left the company as part of the executive level consolidation. Currently, a search is underway for a chief jewelry merchant to take her place.
Capital expenditures are also on the block, meaning that previously launched plans to fully remodel 70 stores this year to its new "Class I" prototype are on hold. Last year, the company remodeled 73 stores to its smaller format and completed a partial, less expensive "Class II" retrofit at its remaining 146 locations.
Before the remodeling program resumes, Cusano said, the first priority will be to secure sublease deals at all fully remodeled stores. So far, the chain has received court approval to sublet space at 35 of these Class I stores and 10 Class II sites to specialty retailers such as TJ. Maxx and Best Buy.
Roughly half of each store's space opened up as a result of product category elimination and the new format, reducing the average box size from 50,000 sq. ft. to 25,000 sq. ft. Last year, the chain sold $200 million in electronics, fitness equipment and toys, following a decision to exit those and other unprofitable merchandise categories.
Although more store closures are always a possibility--127 stores have been shut down since 1999--Cusano said significant downsizing of the current 218-store base is not expected. 'You'll see a couple of closings from us, but there's no major closure program anticipated at this point," he said.
Other means of reducing expenses involve cutting bankruptcy-related professional expenses this year by at least 25%. About the only expense untouched by significant cost cutting is advertising, Cusano said, since effective marketing will be key to the chain's new positioning. In an effort to grow sales, he said advertising would present a "stronger value image" this year.
Even though the company had submitted a plan of exiting bankruptcy by mid-year, Cusano said a tougher retail environment may prompt the chain to work with its creditors on a postponement. He said December's results may be the precursor of a difficult first half.
"We found our business on the jewelry side weaker at the higher price points and stronger at the lower price points," he said of December sales, with jewelry sales soft overall. As a whole, he said the jewelry industry was one of the hardest hit this past holiday season.
Internet sales were also disappointing during the holidays, while home-related goods sales "did not perform badly," Cusano added.
While the company described the holiday season as one of the most difficult in recent years, with sales not meeting goals, early results indicated the company's overall financial performance for the year should at least exceed that of 1999, when a $243.7 million loss was reported. Earnings before interest, taxes and restructuring expenses were on target to be in the range of $30 to $33 million for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 2000, as compared with $25.2 million in 1999.
Those same early results indicated overall sales coming in 3.4% below plan and gross margin results 1.4% below plan, with the home business segment exceeding its gross profit goals and jewelry falling short.

The name of South Asian countries and Bangladesh cannot be ignored when it comes to these shoes. Countries other than Spain uses jute instead of Esparto grass for manufacturing these shoes. Jute in fact has a distinctive white colour and this gives the soles of the shoes a bright white colour making them easily distinguishable from a mile away.

If you think that these shoes
christian louboutin shoes are very pricey, you are again wrong. They come at very affordable prices and are very comfortable. This style shoe is cheap because of a simple reason. These shoes are actually considered as poor person's shoes. Although these shoes have become the darling of cool and hip urban fashion victims but they were actually invented as hard wearing anc cheap footwear for farmers and peasants and all other people who worked in fields.
Espadrilles during those days were mainly popular for their soles. The soles were in fact made of cheap and abundant grass, which was actually native to that area. The grass popularly known as Esparto were shaped, braided and moduled into the shape of the sole. A cotton or canvas fabric upper is basically stitched into the sole and when needed rubber or wooden heels are glued on to it. These shoes came up in laces and also as slip on pairs. So, the cheap and plenty-full grass used as raw materials in these shoes made the footwear very cheap to produce. They were in fact just the perfect kind of shoes for villagers.

You can also find many local companies manufacturing these shoes using poor quality materials. Thus you must be very particular about the brand you choose to opt for when buying a pair of espadrille.
Less authentic versions of espadrilles are made with soles made of rubber or other synthetic materials, which are styles to look like rope soles. These shoes are then painted white in order to give that special espadrille look.

Ankle Boot refers to a short boot which covers only the foot and ankle. Ankle Boots are like regular boots, but they only go up to your ankle, instead of your knee or halfway up your calves.
Ballet Flats also flat shoes, refer to light flat hard-soled shoes resembling those worn by a ballet dancer.
D'Orsay refers to women's pump or slipper with circular vamp.
Espadrilles refers to a shoes usually having a fabric upper part and a sole made of a flexible material, such as rope or rubber.

Gladiator refers to shoes, sandals and etc. derived from ancient roman fighters who were called gladiators. The Gladiator sandal is an extreme example. By definition the gladiator sandal is a flat sandal that has several straps across the top holding the sole to the foot and a strap around the ankle. This sandal worn by the professional fighters was brought back to fashion in the late 1960s and now in 2008 it is making a comeback.
Knee Boots are boots that rise to the knee, or slightly there under. They are generally tighter around the
red soled shoes leg shaft and ankle than at the top. Mostly made of a synthetic rubber (PVC, Neoprene, etc.), they are used by fishermen, dairy workers, stable hands, duck hunters, clammers, etc. to protect the feet from water, mud, manure, etc. and to provide traction on slippery surfaces. Most slip on, but there are varieties with buckles and those that lace up. Certain types can also be known as muckers or fishing boots.
Mary Janes are a type of shoe that can be high heels or regular shoe. Mary Jane's usually have the strap around the ankle or over the top of your foot.
Pumps refers to women's low-cut, low-heeled, thin-soled, casual shoes.
Sandal usually refers to shows with leather sole attached
christian louboutin outlet to foot by straps.
Spectator Pumps refers to women's medium-heeled shoe with contrasting colors at heel and toe of upper.
Thigh Boots refer to boots extending to mid-thigh, flexible at knee.Thong refers to a kind of sandal with strip of material fitted between toes, strapped across foot.
